q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: A good deal of the political advertising literature in recent years has focused on the effects of negative political advertising. Books, such as In Defense of Negativity (Geer 2006) and The Positive Case for Negative Campaigning (Mattes and Redlawsk 2014), have argued that negative ads are more engaging and more informative for citizens than other types of ads. In fact, it would not be a stretch to say that there is something of a consensus among scholars that negative ads are good for democracy. Yet, earlier work in the field made the case that contrast or comparative ads—ads that both advocated a candidate and criticized his or her opponent, usually by contrasting their positions on issues—contribute the most to democratic discourse by making it easier to compare candidates, thus encouraging more deliberative decision-making. Several studies tried to establish whether this was true and concluded that it was not. This study argues the methods of these earlier studies were flawed and will offer experimental evidence to determine if comparative information does in fact promote cognitive processing, paying careful attention to how it interacts with political sophistication. In addition, this study will test whether comparative information increases ambivalence among those exposed to it.

q16.value: The main hypothesis is that respondents will be more likely to cognitively process comparative information than positive or negative information but these effects will be strongest for political sophisticates and will only help political novices in the presence of partisan cues. To test this hypothesis, I will measure how much respondents can recall from ads, as well as their political sophistication. The treatments will vary in terms of ad tone and the strength of partisan cues they contain. My second hypothesis is that comparative information will cause more ambivalence in respondents than positive and negative information, particularly among weak partisans in the non-partisan condition. To test this hypothesis, I will measure respondent ambivalence between the candidate mentioned in the treatment and his opponent. I will also measure respondent’s strength of partisanship. Again, the treatments will vary in terms of ad tone the strength of partisan cues they contain. My third hypothesis is that attention will not explain why comparative information is more likely to be retained than positive and negative information. It is more likely to be due to the “spreading activation” of cognitive activity. To test this hypothesis, I will measure how long respondents engage with the treatment as well as their political sophistication and whether it enables them to take advantage of comparative information. Finally, respondents will claim positive information is more informative than comparative and negative information despite learning less from it. Here I will use a measure of reported informativeness and compare it to actual learning.

q17.value: A 3x3 between subjects experiment will be embedded in a Qualtrics survey that will be administered through Amazon Mechanical Turk (AMT) to approximately 1500 adults in the United States. Participants will first be asked a series of demographic questions. They will then be shown a flyer for a gubernatorial candidate named Michael Velen (see survey for treatments). All treatments include Velen’s name and a list of six issue positions. The treatments will vary by ad tone (positive, comparative, and negative) and the strength of partisan cues contained in the flyer (non-partisan, weak, and strong). Exposure to the treatment will be followed by manipulation checks, distraction tasks (a modified need-for-cognition test and a 10-item personality test), measures of interest related to recall and feelings about the candidate sponsoring the flyer, and then by various questions regarding political attitudes.

In addition, this study will test whether comparative information increases ambivalence among those exposed to it.

attributes.title: Putting Candidates in Context: The Interactive Effects of Candidates and Speech Complexity

q1.value: Putting Candidates in Context: The Interactive Effects of Candidates and Speech Complexity

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Do differences in candidate speech complexity matter to voter’s decision making? What role do the candidates themselves play in this process? Through the use of a novel survey experiment, we examine the interactive effects of candidate and speech complexity on voter candidate evaluation.

q16.value: See attached paper for specific hypotheses, as well as theoretical reasoning. General hypotheses include (1) perceived candidate sophistication and message complexity will affect voters propensity for supporting candidates and (2) voters will use specific strategies when evaluating the interaction between perceived candidate sophistication and message complexity.

q17.value: Data will be collected through respondents on MTurk. See attached paper for details on the experimental design, treatment conditions, and measures to be collected.

attributes.title: Determinants of Public Support for Embedded Liberalism in the United States: A Survey Experiment

q1.value: Determinants of Public Support for Embedded Liberalism in the United States: A Survey Experiment

q5.value: We gratefully acknowledge that this project is partially funded by the following programs: ECONTribute (University of Cologne), Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG, German Research Foundation) – project number 374666841 – SFB 1342, University of Warwick Faculty of Social Sciences Research Development Fund

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: The aim of this experimental study is to better understand the determinants of public support for embedded liberalism – the idea that economic openness is desirable if its distributional consequences are compensated through state spending. Our central research question is under what conditions do people demand protection in the form of restrictive trade and immigration policies, rather than protection in the form of the welfare state? We experimentally test whether compensatory mechanisms increase public support for economic openness in the contemporary US context. Unlike previous experimental work on the topic, our study examines a range of different compensatory mechanisms (social insurance, social assistance, social investment, and welfare chauvinist policies), with the expectation that support for embedded liberalism depends on the type of compensatory policy offered. Drawing on a strong scholarly consensus that education is of central importance in explaining support for both compensatory government spending and economic openness, we also examine how education affects support for embedded liberalism. We expect on the whole that education increases the likelihood that an individual seeks economic protection through compensatory state spending rather than through restrictive trade or immigration policies. Furthermore, we test separate exploratory hypotheses about what type of compensatory spending is most important at different levels of education. Finally, we examine whether individual support for embedded liberalism is sensitive to different sources of economic threat. Notwithstanding recent work highlighting how people tend to misattribute threats from automation to globalization, we expect policy preferences to respond rationally to the source of economic risk. In other words, we expect that people are more likely to prefer protectionist trade and immigration policies to compensatory spending when primed with the threat of immigration, rather than when primed with the threat of automation.

q16.value: H1a Protectionist trade and immigration policies are stronger predictors of policy package choice when they form part of a policy package alongside less compensatory social policies. H1b Compensatory social policies are stronger predictors of policy package choice when they form part of a policy package alongside liberal trade and immigration policies. H1c Support for protectionist trade and immigration policies is weaker among respondents randomly primed with a textual treatment that draws attention to the protection offered by the welfare state, than among respondents that receive no such treatment. H2a Protectionist immigration and trade policies will increase the probability that a policy package is preferred for low educated respondents, and decrease the probability that a policy package is preferred for better-educated respondents. H2b Compensatory social policies targeted on the poor will increase the probability that a policy package is preferred for low educated respondents, and decrease the probability that a policy package is preferred for better-educated respondents. H2c Compensatory social insurance policies will not significantly affect the probability that a policy package is preferred for low educated respondents, and increase the probability that a policy package is preferred for better-educated respondents. H2d Compensatory social investment policies will increase the probability that a policy package is preferred for both low educated respondents and better-educated respondents. H2e Compensatory welfare chauvinist policies will increase the probability that a policy package is preferred for low educated respondents, and decrease the probability that a policy package is preferred for better-educated respondents H3a Respondents primed with a graph/headline about job losses from automation will be less likely to favor restrictive immigration policies than respondents primed with a graph/headline about job losses from immigration. H3b Respondents primed with a graph/headline about job losses from automation will be less likely OR neither less nor more likely to favor restrictive trade policies than respondents primed with a graph/headline about job losses from immigration. H3c Respondents primed with a graph/headline about job losses from automation will be no more or less likely to favor more generous social policies than respondents primed with a graph/headline about job losses from immigration. H3d When primed with a graph/headline about job losses from automation, better-educated respondents should be more likely than less educated respondents to prefer protection through the welfare state, rather than through more restrictive immigration policies.

q17.value: Conjoint analysis: Respondents choose between two policy packages composed of two more or less protectionist immigration and trade policies, and three more or less compensatory social policies. We examine the interactions between policy attributes, observing whether protectionist trade and immigration policies become stronger predictors of which policy package respondents choose when combined with less compensatory social policies. We also analyze the outcome of the conjoint by sub-group, comparing the effects of restrictive trade and immigration policy and various types of compensatory state spending on the likelihood of a policy package being chosen by a) low-educated and b) better-educated groups. Priming experiment: We split our sample into a control and a treatment group. Each group receives a short statement about economic insecurity in the US, but the treatment group receives additional information about the impact of social policy on poverty. Respondents in both groups receive three outcome questions measuring their support for social spending, immigration restrictions, and trade restrictions. The order of the three outcome questions is randomized. Parallel vignette experiments: In the first group, each respondent has a probability of 0.33 of being assigned a newspaper headline about job losses due to automation (threat of automation prime), a newspaper headline about job losses due to immigration (threat of immigration prime), or no prime (control). In the second group, each respondent has a probability of 0.33 of being assigned a table about job losses due to automation (threat of automation prime), a graph about job losses due to immigration (threat of immigration prime), or no prime (control). Respondents in each group receive outcome questions measuring their support for social spending, and immigration restrictions. The order of the outcome questions is randomized.

attributes.title: Group Identity Formation in Response to Group Experiences

q1.value: Group Identity Formation in Response to Group Experiences

q2.value: Molly Offer-Westort | Gregory Huber | Alan Gerber

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: This study addresses how individuals respond to perceived group experiences in an experimental setting, and in particular how group experiences may affect group identity and intra- and inter-group behavior. Participants will undergo an experience (here, positive, negative, or neutral adjustments to a bonus on Amazon Mechanical Turk), and will be randomly assigned to share this experience with a group, or to undergo the experience individually. Behavioral games will measure how the group vs. individual nature of the experience affects behavior towards other in- and out-group participants.

q16.value: Participants who have undergone the experience as a group will exhibit greater generosity and increased norms of reciprocity toward their in-group, and decreased generosity toward the out-group, as compared to participants who have undergone the same experience as individuals.

q17.value: Outcomes will be measured in behavioral games following the experimental intervention, including a modified dictator game, a classical dictator game, and an ultimatum game. Comparisons will be made between individuals who have experienced an adjustment to their bonus as a group, and those who have experienced the adjustment individually.

registration_responses.q2: Molly Offer-Westort | Gregory Huber | Alan Gerber

attributes.title: Fiscal Consolidation and Time Inconsistent Policy Preferences

q1.value: Fiscal Consolidation and Time Inconsistent Policy Preferences

q2.value: Evelyne Hübscher | Thomas Sattler | Zbigniew Truchlewski

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Existing research finds that voters disapprove of both fiscal deficits (Peltzmann 1992) and fiscal adjustments at the same time (Pierson 1994, 2001; Hübscher et al. 2018). This points to a trade-off between deficits and austerity in fiscal policymaking. This trade-off exists because both deficits and austerity negatively affect the utility of a typical voter: greater austerity also has costs because it negatively affects growth and personal disposable income; greater deficits have costs because the additional debt eventually needs to be repaid in the future. Moreover, fiscal deficits and austerity policies are directly linked. If a government cuts spending, the deficit is expected to decrease. To evaluate austerity policies, voters need to decide how much they weight deficits relative to austerity. Unless they put zero weight on deficits, the utility of austerity increases when the deficit becomes larger. We propose that when the prospective, aggregate benefits of fiscal consolidations are uncertain and lie in the future, voters are likely to weight the immediate costs of retrenchment more. It is, thus, plausible that they punish governments and withdraw their support for government parties after a fiscal austerity package. When the benefits of fiscal austerity become visible, however, and the fiscal balance improves, the long-term benefits start to outweigh the short-term costs of austerity.

q16.value: H0: Voters’ policy preferences regarding fiscal consolidation are consistent over time, i.e. consolidation is evaluated equally positive/negative if the voter is looking back as if the voter will experience consolidation now/in the near future. H1: Fiscal consolidation policies will be evaluated more favorably and support for the party having implemented the policy will be stronger if the policy has been implemented in the past than if the policy will be implemented now. H2: On average, respondents are most favorable to a scenario in which the government implemented cuts in the past.

q17.value: In order to test whether voters’ preferences of fiscal consolidation measures are time inconsistent we will conduct a vignette-based experiment embedded in a population survey in which we to expose respondents to scenarios anchored at two different points in time along this process (treatment). The survey experiment will be presented to a sample of citizens in the UK, Germany and Spain. More specifically, some respondents will be presented with a scenario in which cuts happened in the past (2016), some respondents will be presented with a scenario in which cuts are implemented now (2019), a third and last group of respondents will be presented with a scenario in which the government decides to do nothing. We expect to find the following ranking order of respondent’s preferences: 1) Cuts in the past > 2) no cuts > 3) cuts today

attributes.title: Violence, Corruption, and the Redistributive Preferences of Business Interests: Evidence from Mexico

q1.value: Violence, Corruption, and the Redistributive Preferences of Business Interests: Evidence from Mexico

q5.value: This research design was done by Brad Holland & Viridiana Rios

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: The business sector has a diverse and disproportionate influence on public policy and inequality (Przeworski and Wallerstein, 1988; Bernhagen, 2008; Hacker and Pierson, 2010; Bartels, 2016). Although scholars typically viewed business interests as uniformly opposed to progressive taxation and social spending (Esping-Andersen, 1985), researchers in recent decades have increasingly documented systematic variation in business attitudes on social policy (Hall and Soskice, 2001; Swenson, 2002; Mares, 2003; Paster, 2013). However, these more recent studies focus on business interests in advanced democracies, and rarely investigate dynamics in the developing world. This constitutes a signi cant gap: like their counterparts in advanced democracies, business interests in the developing world have varied yet robust political influence (Weymouth, 2012). Moreover, such  forms may face unique contextual factors that influence their redistributive attitudes. Neglecting to account for ways in which particular conditions in the developing countries help shape the attitudes of business interests thus limits our understanding of development and inequality in the developing world. The main objective of this study is to use evidence from a survey experiment of  firm managers and capital investors in Mexico to help address this gap.

q16.value: Hypotheses to be tested: H1/2: Concerns over violence/corruption lead to increased (decreased) support of progressive taxation H3/4: Concerns over violence/corruption lead to increased (decreased) support for welfare programs H5/6: Concerns over violence/corruption increase (decrease) preferences for welfare anti-violence strategies relative to coercive anti-violence strategies. Quantities of interest to be estimated: - To test H1/2: Average of Q2.1- Q2.5; average/individual Q2.6-Q2.7; Q3. - To test H3/4: Individual & average of the answers Q2.1-2.2 - To test H3/4: Answers to individual questions of Q2.1-2.5, Q2.8 - Heterogeneous effects: Q4.1-4.10; additionally we will measure homicides, poverty, Gini.

q17.value: Average Treatment Effects (ATE) for the entire sample; Kernal Regularized Least Square (KRLS) strategies to estimate Marginal Conditional Average Treatment Effects for heterogeneous effects.

attributes.title: Tying their own hands? Why politicians approve laws that might increase accountability against themselves

q1.value: Tying their own hands? Why politicians approve laws that might increase accountability against themselves

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: Brazilian National Congress is voting on a bill on lobbying that promises to increase accountability and control over the relationship between politicians and the business community. The goal is to check if deputies vote to the bill when business associations actually lobby for this.

q16.value: The main hypothesis is that politicians vote on these transparency laws when they are lobbied by interest groups representing business communities. The quantity of interest is the votes of deputies.

q17.value: The project uses a field experiment to test the interest group hypothesis. In April, 2018 the Brazilian Congress is expected to vote a new bill that will regulate lobbying activity. This bill promises to increase transparency in the relationships between politicians and business representatives, and one of its declared goals is to increase the accountability of elected officials. For instance, it will be mandatory for deputies and senators to disclose any meetings with representatives from the private sector, expenditures related to those meetings, or presents and donations received. After several meetings, the NGO Movement Brazil Competitive - which assembles 51 of the largest companies in the country - has agreed to participate in the experiment. The president of the NGO supported the bill and was interested in lobbying politicians for the bill. I have randomized two different messages and send them to the 513 federal deputies’ cell phones.

registration_responses.q1: Tying their own hands? Why politicians approve laws that might increase accountability against themselves

This bill promises to increase transparency in the relationships between politicians and business representatives, and one of its declared goals is to increase the accountability of elected officials. For instance, it will be mandatory for deputies and senators to disclose any meetings with representatives from the private sector, expenditures related to those meetings, or presents and donations received. After several meetings, the NGO Movement Brazil Competitive - which assembles 51 of the largest companies in the country - has agreed to participate in the experiment. The president of the NGO supported the bill and was interested in lobbying politicians for the bill. I have randomized two different messages and send them to the 513 federal deputies’ cell phones.

q2.value: Michaël Aklin | Brian Blankenship | Johannes Urpelainen

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: As India's second largest producer of coal, Jharkhand's economy is heavily dependent on coal mining, and the coal industry employs a signiFIcant portion of the population in a number of districts. However, the state -- much like the rest of India -- is in the midst of a transition in which it is increasing its reliance on renewable sources of energy (Pai and Carr-Wilson, 2018; Tongia and Gross, 2019). As Jharkhand increases its reliance on renewables such as solar, the livelihoods of those involved in the coal industry are uncertain. Indeed, estimates from the World Resources Institute suggest that many new jobs in renewable energy will be temporary, and thus may not make up for the loss of jobs in coal (Jairaj et al., 2018). In this study, we assess preferences for jobs in coal mining versus other jobs, as well as which factors shape these preferences, in order to assess what constitutes an attractive alternative to jobs in the coal mining industry. We are conducting a survey of 1,440 rural households, made up of 10 households per habitation from 144 habitations.

q16.value: Hypothesis 1a. Respondents are more likely to choose jobs that provide more income per week. Hypothesis 1b. Respondents' preference for the job they select will be stronger the more income per week it provides. Hypothesis 2a. Respondents are more likely to choose jobs that provide more months of employment per year. Hypothesis 2b. Respondents' preference for the job they select will be stronger the more months of employment it provides. Hypothesis 3a. Respondents are more likely to choose jobs that are closer to their homes. Hypothesis 3b. Respondents' preference for the job they select will be stronger the closer it is to their home. Hypothesis 4a. Respondents are more likely to choose jobs that are safe for their health. Hypothesis 4b. Respondents' preference for the job they select will be stronger when it is safe for their health. Hypothesis 5. Respondents' are on average less likely to choose coal mining jobs. Hypothesis 6. Households with more education are more likely to choose jobs that provide more income per week. Hypothesis 7. Households with more monthly expenditures are more likely to choose jobs that provide more income per week. Hypothesis 8. Households with more education are more likely to choose jobs that are closer to their homes. Hypothesis 9. Households closer to a coal mine are more likely to choose jobs in the coal industry. Hypothesis 10. Households who know others that work in the coal industry are more likely to choose jobs in the coal industry.

q17.value: OLS and Bayesian Additive Regression Trees (BART); See PAP for details on estimation.

q27.value: Morsel Research and Development, Lucknow, India

attributes.title: Participation in Kenyan Budget Processes: Empowerment, Governance, and Well-being

q1.value: Participation in Kenyan Budget Processes: Empowerment, Governance, and Well-being

q5.value: we thank the World Bank and the Hewlett Foundation for their generous support of this project

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: The purpose of this research study is to understand how citizens’ participation in budget processes influence perceptions of citizen empowerment and attitudes surrounding government performance, voice in decision-making processes, power over implementation decisions, information transparency, collective action in pursuit of development projects, and equity in terms of outcomes. I want to know what explains citizens’ perceptions of voice and power, and how citizens make decisions on allocating development funds. Several Kenyan counties have adopted public participation in the budget process as one way to comply with requirements in Kenya’s 2010 Constitution. Counties have adopted a variety of mechanisms to foster greater public involvement in their planning and budgeting cycles, and have expressed a demand to make this engagement more meaningful. However, there is currently little data to assess where or why some programs may produce better results than others. The availability of data is critical to strengthening PB as these are rolled out across Kenya. Counties will be better guided to know which programs work, how they work, and why they work. I will collect data on the ways county governments design and implement participatory budgeting programs through surveys at the village and ward level. These surveys will evaluate citizens’ perceptions of empowerment, governance, and human development performance. Policymakers can then use the results to improve participatory program design and performance across Kenya, Africa, and the developing world.

q16.value: This study relies on short surveys of average citizens to build knowledge on citizens’ attitudes, behaviors, and experiences. Survey experiments will allow us to estimate the following quantities of interest: 1. Voice: To what extent do citizens who participate in development budget processes believe these processes let them exercise voice in decision-making? 2. Power and Authority: Where do participants believe local power in development policy resides? Who governs development processes and why? 3. Information: To what extent do participants advance their own development preferences relative to those of the government? 4. Collective action: To what extent are participants willing to contribute voluntary labor or financial support to implement and maintain development projects? 5. Social Equity: To what extent do participants believe these processes benefit disadvantaged or traditionally-marginalized communities?

q17.value: This study relies on short surveys of average citizens to build knowledge on citizens’ attitudes, behaviors, and experiences. Our research team will attend existing budget meetings and ask for volunteers to participate in surveys before and after the meetings begin. Once selected, survey enumerators will obtain participants’consent prior to administering surveys, which randomize questions and vignettes across respondents. We will compare responses of participants in the treatment groupswith those of the control group to evaluate how participants in public budget meetings conceive of voice, power, incorporate information, and evaluate governance.

q19.value: The study sample will consist of local participants in public budget meetings in three Kenyan Counties: Makueni, Elgeyo-Marakwet, and Baringo. The total sample will consist of roughly 4,000 participants in public budget meetings.

q24.value: University of Miami (20180535) and Maseno University Kenya (00612/18)
